etymology.description: semantic: 氵(氵) (shuǐ, "water") + phonetic: 气(气) (qì, "air") = water vapor, steam
etymology.interpretation: 汽(汽) (qì, "steam") cleverly combines the concepts of water and air to represent steam, highlighting its nature as vapor or steam formed from water and air.

examples.chinese: 热水烧开后产生汽(熱水燒開後產生汽)，蒸汽缓缓上升(蒸氣緩緩上升)。
examples.pinyin: Rè shuǐ shāo kāi hòu chǎnshēng qì, zhēngqì huǎnhuǎn shàngshēng.
examples.english: When hot water boils, it produces steam, and the vapor rises slowly.

examples.chinese: 冷空气遇到热水时形成汽(冷空氣遇到熱水時形成汽)，给人带来清凉感觉(給人帶來清涼感覺)。
examples.pinyin: Lěng kōngqì yù dào rè shuǐ shí xíngchéng qì, gěi rén dài lái qīngliáng gǎnjué.
examples.english: When cold air meets hot water, vapor is formed and it gives a refreshing feeling.

examples.chinese: 锅炉中常常产生汽(鍋爐中常常產生汽)，驱动机器运转(驅動機器運轉)。
examples.pinyin: Guōlú zhōng chángcháng chǎnshēng qì, qūdòng jīqì yùnzhuǎn.
examples.english: Steam is often produced in boilers to drive machines.
